I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to conduct a study on market-based 
eco-compensation  mechanisms  in  Beijing.  The  TA  is  included  in  the  country  operations 
business plan, 2013–2015 for the PRC.1 ADB fielded a reconnaissance mission in Beijing on 
26–27 June 2013 and held discussions with the Beijing Finance Bureau, Beijing Municipal 
Bureau of Financial Work, and the China Beijing Environmental Exchange (CBEEX) to clarify 
and  agree  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA.2 The design and monitoring framework of the 
TA is in Appendix 1. 
  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Healthy ecological systems can provide invaluable goods and services to human well-
being, including carbon storage, biodiversity, and recreational and aesthetic functions. In the 
PRC,  the  least  degraded  and  healthiest  ecological  systems  are  located  in  the  rural  or 
underdeveloped areas surrounding the urban areas. The government has prioritized economic 
development and livelihood improvement in these areas to achieve inclusive growth. However, 
development should not compromise the local ecological systems since this can reduce the 
services these ecological systems can provide. 
 
3.  Eco-compensation  provides  an  innovative  way  to  attain  urban–rural  integrated 
development. It allows for rural livelihood improvement while reducing or mitigating some of the 
negative impacts of development on ecosystems, and it conserves the important services they 
provide. The idea is to compensate people for refraining from conducting activities that will 
cause serious damage and impair ecosystem services in fragile or economically important 
ecosystems.  Based  on  accumulated  local  experiences  and  studies,  the  PRC  has  started 
drafting an eco-compensation ordinance that will provide further guidance for establishing or 
operating eco-compensation programs. ADB has been providing substantial support to this 
legislative process, as well as its underlying policy studies.3  
 
4.  Presently, most eco-compensation programs in the PRC are government-driven, relying 
heavily on fiscal transfers between government entities. While this kind of arrangement may be 
effective in certain circumstances, it may not properly reflect the value of ecological services 
provided and the willingness to pay of the beneficiaries. It could therefore fail to fully exploit the 
economic efficiency embodied in the principle of eco-compensation. The introduction of market-
based mechanisms for eco-compensation is expected to achieve higher economic efficiency as 
the valuations of service providers and beneficiaries would be better revealed and realized.

5.  Among the goods and services an ecological system offers, carbon sequestered in land 
and forests accounts for a large share in terms of economic values. In the agricultural sector, 
soil improvement can increase sequestration. Emission reductions may be achieved through 
changing cultivars, feed, or composition of livestock and herds, and through other sustainable 
agricultural  practices.  In  the  forestry  sector,  management  practices  that  increase  carbon 
sequestration include conservation, afforestation, or reforestation. Reductions in emissions can 
be  achieved  through  reduced  impact  logging  and  other  sustainable  forestry  practices.  In 
voluntary or mandatory carbon trading markets, carbon credits are generally generated through 
measurements of the current amounts of carbon sequestered in the soil and trees, and the 
potential additional carbon sequestration is achieved through various management practices. A 
ton of carbon reduced generates a single credit. This credit is then sold to offset emissions from 
the purchaser, or it may be purchased and retired to reduce total emissions. In sum, carbon 
sequestration from the agriculture and forestry sectors is an ecological service that could be 
incorporated into market-based transactions.  
 
6.  Therefore,  a  natural  starting  point  and  focus  of  developing  market-based  eco-
compensation mechanisms would be incorporating carbon sequestration from the agriculture 
and forestry sectors into carbon emission trading markets. Although extensive literature exists 
with respect to carbon sequestration and eco-compensation mechanisms in various ecosystems, 
many issues need to be addressed within the PRC context. These include (i) the calculation of 
the amount of carbon sequestered and the potential for additional sequestration in rural areas of 
Beijing, (ii) the appropriate methodology for verifying the amount of carbon sequestered and 
generating carbon credits, (iii) practical ways to incorporate carbon sequestration into a cap-
and-trade program, (iv) the economic benefits and transaction costs of a carbon trade program 
involving  carbon  sequestration,  and  (v)  the  approaches  on  how  market  mechanisms  and 
government-driven eco-compensation programs can better complement each other.  
 
7.  The proposed TA will address the above issues, with a geographical focus in Beijing 
Municipality. Beijing was chosen for the following reasons: 
(i)  Beijing is prepared to launch a local carbon trading market by the end of 2013, 
one  of  seven  pilot  programs  nationwide.  Of  the  total  allowance,  5%  will  be 
allocated to carbon sequestered in agricultural and forestry sectors, although it is 
unclear  to  policy  makers  and  practitioners  how  the  two  sectors  will  be 
incorporated into the carbon market. The TA will directly contribute to the design 
of the experiment in a timely manner.  
(ii)  Ecological services provided in the rural area of Beijing are highly valuable and 
cannot  be  easily  replaced,  while  the  need  for  rural  development  remains  a 
challenge to Beijing. 
(iii)  As a leading city in carbon market development, Beijing’s experience could serve 
as a model for other local governments, and the central government who aims to 
design a national market after 2015.  
(iv)  The TA can build upon the existing assistance provided by ADB to the Beijing 
Municipality and CBEEX on its strategic development in carbon finance and thus 
extend ADB’s value-addition. 4 
 
8.  Increasing  carbon  sequestration  through  afforestation,  forest  management,  and 
conservation; improving ecological compensation mechanisms; and controlling greenhouse gas

emissions  from  agricultural  practices  and  animal  husbandry  are  among  the  key  activities 
highlighted in the State Council’s document.5 The proposed TA will provide direct support to 
these  national  priorities.  ADB’s  PRC  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015  specifically 
identifies  promoting  integrated  rural  and  urban  development  and  the  development  and 
institutionalization  of  green  financing  instruments  to  support  PRC’s  inclusive  and 
environmentally  sustainable  growth.6 The  proposed  TA  directly  contributes  to  these  tasks 
through developing market-based mechanisms to compensate rural residents for conserving 
ecological services. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be improved rural ecological systems (as indicated by 1 million tons of 
carbon credits generated from rural Beijing) and residential livelihoods in Beijing (as indicated 
by the CNY10 million in revenues received by residents of rural Beijing from the sale of carbon 
credits).  The  outcome  will  be  the  establishment  of  market-based  eco-compensation 
mechanisms in Beijing with major findings and policy recommendations from the TA adopted by 
the government. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The primary output of the TA will be a main report on developing market-based eco-
compensation  mechanisms.  The  report  will  have  four  sub-reports,  which  will  examine  the 
following topics:  
(i)  Potential  and  valuation  of  carbon  sequestered  in  the  agricultural  and 
forestry sectors in rural Beijing. Specifically, the sub-report will identify the 
possible types of activities to increase carbon sequestration in rural areas of 
Beijing, quantify the existing and potential amounts of carbon sequestrated in 
farmland and forests, and assess a means to capitalize the sequestered carbon. 
(ii)  Development of a carbon trading market incorporating the forestry and 
agricultural  sectors.  Based  on  a  review  of  international  experience  and 
strategies of carbon trading markets in the PRC, the sub-report will investigate 
the effective institutional arrangements to introduce carbon credits derived from 
the agricultural and forestry sectors into a carbon trading program in Beijing. 
(iii)  Economic analysis of carbon trading involving the agricultural and forestry 
sectors.  The  sub-report  will  assess  the  economic  costs  of  maintaining  and 
increasing carbon sequestration in rural areas of Beijing, transaction costs for 
trading carbon credits from the agricultural and forestry sectors, and ways to 
distribute the revenues from selling carbon credits among contributors.  
(iv)  Fiscal policies and market-based eco-compensation mechanisms. Issues to 
be explored include how the fiscal policies and tools can support the carbon 
trading involving the agricultural and forestry sectors and how the system can 
complement existing eco-compensation programs relying on public transfer.     
 
11.   Based on the major findings and recommendations of the main report, a policy note on 
the development of market-based eco-compensation mechanisms in Beijing will be prepared

government. The policy note is expected to be adopted by the Beijing Municipal Government for

sectors for cost-effective reduction of carbon emissions.  
 
12.  Under government financing, the TA will also support the executing agency and the 
implementing  agency,  with  assistance  from  consultants,  to  organize  and/or  participate  in 
international conferences on market-based eco-compensation mechanisms for the purpose of 
disseminating the information and knowledge generated from the TA. The TA will also provide 
capacity building related to policy and practice of market-based eco-compensation to policy 
makers and potential stakeholders through study tours and trainings. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The CBEEX will 
provide $290,000 equivalent in cash to fund study tours, workshops and conferences, and 
training.7 The CBEEX will also provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation and utilities, data and documents, site transport and other logistical support, 
and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Beijing Municipal Bureau of Financial Work will be the executing agency and the 
CBEEX will be the implementing agency. The executing agency will provide overall guidance 
and  coordination  among  relevant  government  agencies.  The  implementing  agency  is 
responsible for carrying out the TA activities and providing counterpart financing. A technical 
management  office  will  be  established  at  the  implementing  agency  for  the  day-to-day 
implementation and management of the TA.  
 
15.  The TA will be partially delegated to the executing agency.8 A procurement capacity 
assessment was conducted on the executing agency and implementing agency in 2010 during 
the preparation of the Study on Beijing Green Finance Development Strategy (footnote 4) by the 
TA project team and the then Central Operations Services Office (now the Operations Services 
and  Financial  Management  Department).  The  assessment  concluded  that  the  agencies’ 
capacity was satisfactory and that ADB provided substantial support and guidance throughout 
the implementation process given that it was the first TA to be undertaken by both agencies. 
There have been no adverse changes to the executing and implementing agencies’ capacity 
since the assessment was completed. 
 
16.  The proposed TA will be implemented over 18 months, tentatively from 1 October 2013 
to 31 March 2015. The TA requires an estimated 8 person-months of international and 26 
person-months  of  national  consultants  with  expertise  in  the  areas  of  carbon  market 
development, forestry and agricultural carbon sinks, agricultural economics, rural development, 
and fiscal policy. The outline terms of reference for consultants are provided in Appendix 3.

17.  The consultants will be engaged through a consulting firm by the executing agency in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time), using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The 
simplified technical proposal approach will be used. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Resource persons will be invited to review the consultants’ outputs and share 
knowledge  during  workshops  and  conferences  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  guidelines  on 
recruiting and administering resource persons. 
 
18.  The outputs are expected to be disseminated through (i) a policy note to be presented to 
key government agencies, (ii) an international conference to be conducted on market-based 
eco-compensation  mechanisms,  and  (iii)  training  materials  to  be  produced  that  target 
government agencies and the private sector.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Market-Based Eco-Compensation 
Mechanisms in Beijing, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  Carbon  market  specialist  and  team  leader  (national,  8  person-months).  The 
consultant must have (i) a doctorate degree in agriculture, forestry, or other relevant fields; (ii) 8 
or more years of work experience related to carbon trading or carbon market development; (iii) 
adequate knowledge on the history, policies, and trends of global carbon markets, as well as the 
pilot carbon trading programs of the People’s Republic of China (PRC); and (iv) experience in 
leading agricultural or forestry carbon projects. The consultant must be fluent in both written and 
oral English. The carbon market specialist and team leader will be responsible for the timely 
delivery and quality of the final outputs of the technical assistance (TA), as well as for the daily 
coordination and supervision of the consultant team. Specifically, the carbon market specialist 
and team leader will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  develop the detailed framework and methodology for the TA in consultation with 
the executing agency, implementing agency, and other stakeholders;  
(ii)  develop outlines of the inception, interim, and final reports for the TA, and assign 
work to respective specialists on the team; 
(iii)  conduct inception, midterm, and final workshops to review project progress and 
discuss outputs, and engage resource persons for the workshops with guidance 
from ADB and the executing agency; 
(iv)  manage and ensure timely implementation of TA activities, including field visits 
and  data  collection;  stakeholder  consultations;  reports  and  policy  note 
preparation; holding of inception, interim, and final workshops; and other related 
activities; 
(v)  coordinate  and  compile  inputs  from  team  members,  and  finalize  various  TA 
reports, including inception, interim, and final reports; 
(vi)  lead the preparation of the sub-report on development of carbon trading market 
to incorporate agricultural and forestry sectors;

forestry bureau. These communications include providing a briefing of the TA

3.  Carbon market specialist (international, 3 person-months). The consultant must have 
(i) a postgraduate degree in agriculture, forestry, or other relevant fields; (ii) 5 or more years of 
work experience related to carbon trading or carbon market development; and (iii) adequate 
knowledge of the development of international carbon trading schemes involving agricultural 
and/or forestry carbon credits. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review and summarize international policies, studies, and practices related to 
carbon trading schemes involving agricultural and/or forestry carbon sinks; 
(ii)  assist the team leader in preparing the sub-report on the development of carbon 
trading markets to incorporate agricultural and forestry carbon sequestration and 
emissions  avoidance,  which  should  examine  the  applicability  of  international 
experience in the PRC and explore practical ways to apply this experience in 
designing PRC carbon trading schemes; 
(iii)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(iv)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and international study tours; 
(v)  assist the team leader in improving the English versions of TA reports, the policy 
note, conference proceedings, and other related materials; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
4.  Forestry  carbon  specialists  (international,  3  person-months;  national,  4  person-
months). The consultants must have (i) a postgraduate degree in forestry or other relevant 
fields, (ii) 5 or more years of work experience in forestry carbon projects and forestry research 
projects, and (iii) adequate knowledge of the status and trends of global and domestic forestry 
carbon programs. Knowledge of the forestry sector of Beijing or the central and western PRC as 
well as experience with REDD+ project is desirable.1 The national consultant must be fluent in 
both written and oral English. The specialists will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review and summarize methodology and practices of measuring and verifying 
forestry  carbon  sequestration;  international  and  domestic  experiences  in 
developing forestry carbon projects; and required laws, regulations, and policies 
for the forestry carbon sink development; 
(ii)  conduct  field  visits  and  data  collection  to  obtain  a  comprehensive,  detailed 
understanding of forestry carbon sinks in rural Beijing, particularly various forest 
and soil types, the amount of carbon currently sequestered,  the relationship

conservation and sustainable management of forests and the enhancement of forest carbon stocks.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
between  forest  quality  and  carbon  sequestration,  the  potential  for  additional 
carbon  sequestration,  and  approaches  and  costs  to  achieving  carbon 
sequestration, among others;  
(iii)  prepare the sub-reports on the potential and valuation of the carbon sequestered 
in the forestry sector in rural Beijing as well as an economic analysis of carbon 
trading engaging the forestry sector in rural Beijing; 
(iv)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(v)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and study tours; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
5.  Agricultural  carbon  specialists  (international 2 person-months; national, 4 person-
months). The consultants must have (i) a postgraduate degree in agriculture or other relevant 
fields, (ii) 5 or more years of work experience in agricultural carbon projects, and (iii) adequate 
knowledge  of  the  status  and  trends  of  global  and  domestic  agricultural  carbon  programs. 
Experience with the agricultural sector of Beijing and agricultural carbon projects is desirable. 
The national consultant must be fluent in both written and oral English. The specialists will 
perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review  and  summarize  methodology  and  practices  of measuring  and verifying 
agricultural  carbon  sequestration;  international  and  domestic  experiences  in 
developing  agricultural  carbon  projects;  and  required  laws,  regulations,  and 
policies for agricultural carbon development; 
(ii)  conduct  field  visits  and  data  collection  to  obtain  a  comprehensive,  detailed 
understanding  of  agricultural  carbon  sinks  in  rural  Beijing,  particularly  various 
types of agricultural carbon sinks, the amount of carbon currently sequestered, the 
potential  for  additional  carbon  sequestration,  and  approaches  and  costs  to 
achieving carbon sequestration, among others; 
(iii)  prepare the sub-reports on the potential and valuation of the carbon sequestered 
in the agricultural sector in rural Beijing as well as an economic analysis of carbon 
trading engaging the agricultural sector in rural Beijing; 
(iv)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(v)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and study; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
6.  Agricultural economist (national, 4 person-months). The consultant must have (i) a 
postgraduate degree in agricultural economics or other relevant fields; (ii) 5 or more years of 
work  experience  in  agricultural  economy,  agricultural  industrialization,  or  agricultural 
modernization; and (iii) adequate knowledge of carbon markets and carbon credits generated 
from  the  agricultural  sector,  rural  low-carbon  development,  and  the  history  and  trends  of 
agricultural development both globally and in the PRC. The consultant must be fluent in both 
written and oral English. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review and summarize literature on costs of agricultural carbon sequestration 
and impacts of agricultural carbon trading on agricultural development; 
(ii)  conduct  careful  assessment  of  the  specific  agricultural  activities  required  to 
generate carbon credits and associated costs in rural Beijing, and compare costs 
of other carbon emission reduction measures based on field visits and data 
analysis;

Appendix 3  13 
(iii)  assist agricultural carbon specialists in preparing the sub-reports on the potential 
and valuation of carbon sequestered in the agricultural sector in rural Beijing as 
well as an economic analysis of carbon engaging the agricultural sector in rural 
Beijing; 
(iv)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(v)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and study tours; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
7.  Rural development specialist (national, 3 person-months). The consultant must have (i) 
a postgraduate degree in rural development or other relevant fields; (ii) 5 or more years of 
relevant work experience, including in conducting rural household surveys; and (iii) adequate 
knowledge of eco-compensation policies and practices. The consultant must be fluent in both 
written and oral English. Experience with rural development projects in Beijing is desirable. The 
specialist will perform the following tasks:   
(i)  review  and  summarize  domestic  and  international  experience  in  eco-
compensation  for  rural  eco-system  conservation,  particularly  farmland  and 
forests;  
(ii)  assess impacts of agricultural and forestry carbon trading on rural development 
and livelihood in Beijing;  
(iii)  design  mechanisms  to  channel  revenues  from  carbon  trading  to  ecological 
service providers and to maximize benefits from trading for the poor population in 
rural areas; 
(iv)  assist the team leader in coordinating field visits and data collection;  
(v)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(vi)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and study tours; and 
(vii)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader. 
 
8.  Fiscal policy specialist (national, 3 person-months). The consultant must have (i) a 
postgraduate degree in public finance, fiscal policy, or other relevant fields; (ii) 5 or more years 
of  experience  in  public  policy  and  fiscal-supported  eco-compensation  programs;  and  (iii) 
adequate  knowledge  of  fiscal  policies  related  to  agriculture,  forestry,  and  climate  change 
mitigation. The consultant must be fluent in both written and oral English. The specialist will 
perform the following tasks: 
(i)  review and summarize domestic and international experiences in fiscal transfer to 
support eco-compensation; 
(ii)  assess  how  fiscal  transfer  programs  and  market-based  eco-compensation 
mechanisms can support and complement each other; 
(iii)  prepare  the  sub-report  on  fiscal  policies  and  market-based  eco-compensation 
mechanisms; 
(iv)  participate in TA activities and contribute to TA outputs as requested by the team 
leader; 
(v)  support  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  in  organizing  the 
international conference and study tours; and 
(vi)  conduct other related work assigned by the team leader.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
C.  Reporting 
9.  The consulting team will submit the following reports: (i) an inception TA report within 2 
months after mobilization or 1 month before the inception workshop, (ii) a revised inception 
report within 15 days after the inception workshop, (iii) an interim TA report within 5 months after 
mobilization or 1 month before the interim workshop, (iv) a revised interim report within 1 month 
after the interim workshop, (v) a draft final report within 8 months after mobilization or 1 month 
before the final workshop, and (vi) a final report 2 months after the final workshop. The revised 
inception report, revised interim report, and the final report should incorporate and address 
comments from the executing agency, implementing agency, relevant government agencies, 
ADB, and other invited reviewers.  
 
10.  A draft policy note will be prepared based on the draft final report and will be finalized 
when the final report is accepted by ADB. Proceedings of the conference will be prepared and 
finalized 2 months after the conference. The training materials will be prepared and finalized 1 
month before the trainings.  
 
11.  All documents will be submitted in both English and Chinese to the executing agency 
and ADB in hard and electronic copies. The documents will be posted online in both languages.
